It is often suggested, especially in a Western context, that without the god-given moral imperatives like the biblical [[10 commandments]], moral standards would eventually evaporate. At least two reports, one by [[paleontologist]], [[author]] and [[illustrator]] [[Gregory S Paul]], and one by [[Gary F. Jensen]] of [[Vanderbilt University]], have addressed this problem using statistics of [[homicide]], [[abortion]], sexually transmittable diseases ([[SDT]]s) and more.
     
Paul argued that such a loss of morality does not seem to be borne out in the data he studied,<ref name = "Paul">[[Gregory S. Paul]] (2005), ''Cross-National Correlations of Quantifiable Societal Health with Popular Religiosity and Secularism in the Prosperous Democracies - A First Look'', Journal of Religion and Society, Volume 7, ISSN 1522-5658 http://moses.creighton.edu/JRS/2005/2005-11.html </ref> based on a study of many western countries but, with a focus of the bad outcome of the US: "Pressing questions include the reasons, whether theistic or non-theistic, that the exceptionally wealthy U.S. is so inefficient that it is experiencing a much higher degree of societal distress than are less religious, less wealthy prosperous democracies." However, an analysis published later in the same journal that published Paul's study contends that a number of methodological problems undermine any findings or conclusions to be taken from his research.<ref>{{cite journal| url=http://moses.creighton.edu/JRS/2006/2006-1.html| journal=Journal of Religion and Society| title=Religiosity, Secularism, and Social Health| author=Gerson Moreno-Riaño| coauthors=Mark Caleb Smith, Thomas Mach|location=Cedarville University| year=2006| volume=8}}</ref>
